thread.title: Sam Harper hospitalised: Travis Head’s harsh Sheffield Shield decision
thread.title_full: Sam Harper hospitalised: Travis Head’s harsh Sheffield Shield decision

author: Tyson Otto
title: Sam Harper hospitalised: Travis Head’s harsh Sheffield Shield decision
text:
SOUTH Australian captain Travis Head has refused to allow Victoria a replacement player after the Bushrangers’ wicketkeeper was hospitalised on Saturday from a blow to the head. 
Harris was struck on the helmet by the bat of Redbacks batsman Jake Lehmann when keeping to spinner Jon Holland during South Australia’s first innings at the Adelaide Oval.
Lehmann tried to pull Holland’s bouncing delivery and hit Harris in the head on his follow-through.
The 20-year-old keeper fell to the turf and appeared appeared significantly distressed, but was able to walk off the field with assistance from medical staff.
An update confirmed Harper was conscious and talking, but was taken to hospital for scans.
An extended lunch break was taken after the injury.
It’s the second time this summer a wicketkeeper has been struck by a bat, after Melbourne Renegades wicketkeeper Peter Nevill was hit by a flying bat during the Big Bash League.
After receiving treatment on the field, Harris was taken to Royal Adelaide Hospital.
“He (Harper) was examined at Adelaide Oval by medical staff before being transferred to hospital for further assessment and treatment,” a Victorian Cricket statement said.
“Harper underwent scans this afternoon which have not identified any bleeding or bone damage, but he will remain in hospital overnight for observation.”
Victoria wicketkeeper Sam Harper was taken to hospital. Source: Supplied 
During the extended break Head and Victorian captain Cameron White met to discuss the options available to both teams after Harris was immediately ruled out of playing any further part in the Shield match.
Victorian coach and former Australian Test allrounder Andrew McDonald said Victoria formerly requested to replace Harris with a substitute player for the remainder of the match, but was denied by the home team.
Under Sheffield Shield rules opposition captains have the ability — in the spirit of the game — to decide if their opposition are able to replace injured players.
McDonald diplomatically said Head knocked Victoria’s request back.
“There was some talk behind the scenes, obviously in extenuating circumstances for a replacement player,” McDonald told ABC Grandstand.
“That was requested and obviously in the spirit of the game the two captains can get together. Travis Head had a good think about it. Apparently there was some sort of vote in their dressing room and the end result is that we won’t be able to replace that player in that extenuating circumstance, but that ultimately is South Australia’s decision and Travis Head is ultimately responsible for that decision and he felt that it wasn’t going to be passed by him.”
Travis Head rolling the arm over. Source: News Corp Australia 
The decision leaves Victoria a batsman down in the second innings and without their primary wicketkeeper for South Australia’s second innings run chase.
McDonald said his team’s first priority is the health and welfare of Harris.
He said Harris’ severe concussion diagnosis was extremely good news considering recent head blow injuries in cricket.
“It all looks pretty good for him at the moment.” McDonald said.
“He’s in the Royal Adelaide Hospital receiving some treatment in there. He’s had CT scan and there’s no bleed or fractures or anything serious like that so at this stage it looks like a severe concussion and he’ll be kept in hospital overnight for observation.
“It’s a pretty good result for what we thought was a pretty significant blow to the head. It’s obviously, good news.
“Obviously, he was well treated on the ground and all the correct procedures were followed. Once he got out the back behind the stands everything sort of calmed down a little bit. They stabilised him and things were looking good and there was no significant rush to get him off.
Sam Harper appeared distressed. Source: Supplied 
“At that moment, obviously, players’ minds were flashing here, there and everywhere and it was decided by both captains that a delay was probably best until, particularly Jake Lehmann was ready to continue his innings, until our guys were ready to continue. So common sense prevailed there.”
Victoria established a 70-run overall lead at tea on day two.
South Australia were 9-168 at the time of Harris’ injury and eventually were dismissed for 178, six runs shy of Victoria’s first-innings total.
Lehmann was the final wicket to fall, caught off the bowling of Jon Holland (4-26) for a match-high 92.
In reply, the Victorian opening pair made a solid but unspectacular start, putting on 64 from 23 overs in the second innings.
Travis Dean was unbeaten on 23 and Marcus Harris was not out 40.
— with AAP
